{{short description|A social network game played on a two-dimensional matrix}} The '''Poietic Generator''' is a [[social-network game]] designed by [[Olivier Auber]]Olivier Auber, independent researcher, member dof the research cluster of the [http://p2pfoundation.net P2P foundation], affiliated since 2012 to the interdisciplinary research group [http://ecco.vub.ac.be/?q=node/30 "Evolution, Complexity and COgnition" (ECCO), Vrije Universiteit Brussel] and to the [http://globalbraininstitute.org Global Brain Institute]. in 1986, and developed from 1987 under the label [[free art]]Prior the free art license (2000), the Poietic Generator had its own free license: https://web.archive.org/web/20020605145918/http://perso.enst.fr/~auber/sommaireA.html#statut. thanks to many contributors.Poietic Generator's contributors : http://poietic-generator.net/blog/?page_id=91. The game takes place within a two-dimensional matrix in the tradition of [[board games]] and its principle is similar to both [[Conway's Game of Life]] and the [[Surrealism|surrealists]]' [[Exquisite corpse]]. However, it differs from these models in several respects. It is not an algorithm like Conway's, but human players who control in real time the graphic elements of a global matrix, on the basis of one unit per person. Unlike the exquisite corpse, in which there are always hidden parts, here all the players' actions are visible at all times by each of them. Unlike [[board games]], there is no concept of winning or losing, the goal of the game is simply to collectively draw recognizable forms and to observe how we create them together. The name "Poietic Generator", derived from the concept of [[autopoiesis]] in life sciences ([[Francisco Varela]]), and of [[poietic]] in philosophy of art ([[Paul Valéry]], [[:fr:René Passeron|René Passeron]] {{fr}}), illustrates the process of [[self-organization]] at work in the continuous emergence of the global picture. Since its inception, the Poietic Generator has been designed as part of a wider [[action research]] to create an "Art of Speed".''[http://nideffer.net/proj/_SPEED_/1.4/articles/auber.html Esquisse d'une position théorique pour un art de la vitesse]'', Olivier Auber, SPEED 1997. == Rules of the game ==
Every player draws on a small part of a global mosaic formed by the dynamic juxtaposition of those parts, which are manipulated by all the participants (eventually it will be possible for several thousand players to play simultaneously). Every player can therefore change the sign in his/her square, depending on the overall state of the image, which itself depends on the actions of all the individual players. Out of this cybernetic loop emerges a kind of narrative: autonomous forms, sometimes abstract, sometimes figurative, appear in a completely unpredictable manner and tell stories.Olivier Auber, in [http://www.kisskissbankbank.com/fr/projects/generateur-poietique/news/poietic-generator-reloaded-l-aventure-peut-re-commencer ''Poietic Generator reloaded, l'aventure peut (re)commencer !'']
File:Générateur Poïétique, illustration du concept (1988).gif|Illustration of the concept (1988) File:Générateur Poïétique - Du local au global.jpg|Each player draws on one element of the total matrix File:Générateur Poïétique, interface de la version Multicast (1994).gif|Interface, Multicast version (1994) File:Annonce d'une session Poietic Generator sur le Mbone ( février 1996).gif|Announcement of a session on the Mbone (February 1996). Screenshot of the "session directory" (Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory) File:Générateur Poïétique, enregistrement (1995).gif|Recording the first real-time group interaction without any center (1996) File:Générateur Poïétique. Enregistrment d'une expérience sur le web, festival X-00 (2000).gif|Recording of a web experiment, X-00 festival (2000) File:Générateur Poïétique, Elmediator 2005-03-23.gif|Recording of an experiment with the "Elmediator" digital public space (2005-03-23) File:GP20.jpg|Mobile phone user interface(2012) File:Poietic Generator Classroom experiment.jpg|Poietic Generator classroom experiment in Brussels (2013) File:Projection depuis le salon Cutme.jpg|First permanent urban display, Rue du Chien Marin, Brussels. Dec. 2013. |The r/place project involved users being able to edit a pixel every 10 minutes. In practice, each player can draw (using a graphics tablet) on a very simple image. This image is limited in size (20×20 [[pixels]]) by design. This was done to prevent a single player from drawing figurative signs by himself. The overall image is continuously formed in the style of a spiral, that is to say the sign of the first player occupies the whole image, and the signs of the newcomers are juxtaposed in the first winding around it, and so on. If a player forfeits the game, his/her sign immediately disappears and its position remains empty until another player occupies it. A zoom in/zoom out feature ensures that the image constituted by the juxtaposition of all signs, is permanently visible to all the players. == Versions == The Poietic Generator runs on two types of architecture, a centralized network (for versions 1, 3, 4), or an ''[[Ad hoc On-demand Distance Vector|ad hoc]]'' distributed network capable of implementing the [[multicast]] protocol (case version 2). Therefore, no location in the network plays a particular role and according to the rules of the Poietic Generator, an "all-all" interaction may take place without the intervention of any kind of control center. # Videotex version, developed in [[C (programming language)|C]] for the French [[Minitel]] system (1987)Vidéotex version for the Minitel system (1987): deprecated. # IP Multicastversion, developed in [[C (programming language)|C]] for the Internet [[Mbone]] (1995)"gp" IP Multicast version of the Poietic Generator, developed in [[C (programming language)|C]] for the Internet [[Mbone]] (1995): ([http://www.infres.enst.fr/~dax/guides/multicast/mdownload.html Telecom ParisTech server]) # IP Unicast version, developed in [[Java (programming language)|Java]] for the Web (1997)IP Unicast version, developed in [[Java (programming language)|Java]] for the Web (1997)([http://perspective-numerique.net/SOURCES Olivier Auber's server]) # Mobile version developed in [[Ruby on Rails]] and [[JavaScript]] (2012)Mobile version developed in [[Ruby on Rails]] and [[JavaScript]] (2012) ([https://github.com/Gnuside/poietic-generator Github]) This latest version is available on the web,Play over the web : http://play.poietic-generator.net/ via Android mobile phone,[https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.applidium.poieticgen Android app] iPhone / iPad,[https://itunes.apple.com/fr/app/generateur-poietique/id467380785?mt=8 Iphone/Ipad App] via Facebook,[http://www.facebook.com/GenerateurPoietique/app_156218351098324 Play via Facebook] and has a reference site.Reference site: http://poietic-generator.net/blog/ == Experiments == Since 1987, the Poietic Generator (various versions) inspired many experiments in diverse contexts. The first public experiment was at the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]] in 1990 as part of the "Communication and monumentality" exhibition.The exhibition "Communication and monumentality" ([[Centre Georges Pompidou]], 1990) presented the seven laureates of the ''France-Japon Symbol'' contest launched by [[:fr:Philippe Quéau|Philippe Quéau]]. The Poietic Generator was one of them: [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1510/is_n62/ai_7422483/ Charles Lenay "The poietic generator - interactive telecommunication artwork". Whole Earth Review. Spring, 1989] Other museums, art galleries, digital public spaces, festivals,[http://www.x-arn.org/?doc=x-00 Festival X-00, Lorient, France, 16-19 mars 2000], [http://www.nettime.org/Lists-Archives/nettime-fr-0005/msg00005.html ''Théophanie assistée par ordinateur'' BREAK21 festival - Ljubljana, Slovenie, 11 mai 2000] and international conferences,[https://web.archive.org/web/20000524140000/http://simsim.rug.ac.be/mariemont/fr/prog.html Musée Royal de Mariemont : ''art en ligne · art en réseau · art en mouvement'', 6 juin 1999], [[:en:Artmedia|ARTMEDIA]] VIII (Paris 2002) - [http://www.olats.org/projetpart/artmedia/2002/t_oAuber.html Texte d'Olivier Auber] in Dossier Artmedia VIII, in "Ligeia", Paris, 2002, pp. 21-245 (CNRF journal, including Artmedia VIII Proceedings), [[:en:Artmedia|ARTMEDIA]] IX (Salerno 2005) - [http://www.teknemedia.net/magazine_detail.html?mId=712 Annonce] - Mario Costa (ed.) (2005), Phenomenology of New Tech Arts, Salerno: Università di Salerno (Catalog, pp. 56), WJ-SPOTS#1 (Paris 2009) - [http://old.wj-s.org/WJ-SPOTS-1-Paris Web] etc. then followed, including the 1991 "Communicating Machines" exhibition by the [[Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie]] (Paris).[[:fr:Jean-Louis Boissier|Jean-Louis Boissier]], Catalogue de l'exposition « Machines à communiquer faites œuvres », La Communication, Lucien Sfez (éd.), Paris, Presses Universitaires de France et la Cité des sciences et de l'industrie, (1991) Several experiments were performed on the periphery of academic research. For instance, experiments were conducted in particular at [[Telecom ParisTech]] (where Olivier Auber was a guest artist between 1994 and 1997), during the Internet [[Mbone]] experiment (with [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory]] and Xerox PARC), and at other laboratories. The subjects of the experiments were diverse: network protocols, the process of emergence of forms, human-machine interfaces, collective intelligence,''ProspecTic, nouvelles technologies, nouvelles pensées'', Jean-Michel Cornu, FING & Fyp Editions, oct. 2008. ([http://perspective-numerique.net/wakka.php?wiki=ProspecTic Web]) group behavior,Elisa Giaccardi, Center for LifeLong Learning and Design (L3D), Department of Computer Science and Institute of Cognitive Science, University of Colorado : ''Mediators in Visual Interaction: An Analysis of the “Poietic Generator” and “Open Studio”'' ([http://l3d.cs.colorado.edu/~giaccard/research/pdf/Giaccardi_JVLC05.pdf PDF]) etc. Since 1997, the Poietic Generator is accessible to everyone on the web as a work of [[free art]] (under [[Free Art License]] from 2002). At the request of various groups of artists, teachers or researchers, this led to several hundred recordedSome records: [http://perspective-numerique.net/wakka.php?wiki=GenerateurPoietiqueVideos (perspective-numerique.net)] game sessions, some of them commented.Some comments: [http://www.transactiv-exe.org/spip.php?article98 (Transactiv.exe)] In several of these sessions, 70 players participated simultaneously. Several experiments were in kindergarten, elementary and secondary schools (including one experiment linking multiple classrooms). The most recent event was in the spring of 2011 when 70 people responded to a call on the [[France Culture]] radio stationFrance-Culture, [http://www.franceculture.fr/emission-place-de-la-toile-agriculture-machines-et-reseaux-generateur-poietique-2011-04-10.html ''Place de la Toile'', 2011.04.10] ([http://perspective-numerique.net/wakka.php?wiki=PlaceDeLaToile10042011 Audio]) to finance the mobile version of the Poietic Generator via the crowd-funded platform. A call to finance the mobile version of the Poietic Generator [http://www.kisskissbankbank.com/fr/projects/generateur-poietique/news/poietic-generator-english (KissKissBanBank crowdfunding platform)] This version is currently online (2012). == Position in art history == Several art historians and theorists, including [[Don Foresta]],[http://www.donforesta.net/ Don Foresta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018143723/http://www.donforesta.net/ |date=2013-10-18 }}: [http://195.194.24.18/~donforesta/mambo/images/stories/other_docs/annexe_ga2.pdf ''Chronologie historique résumée d'échanges artistiques par télécommunications. Les précurseurs, jusqu'en 1995, avant l'Internet'' (PDF)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517132711/http://195.194.24.18/~donforesta/mambo/images/stories/other_docs/annexe_ga2.pdf |date=2014-05-17 }} [[:pt:Gilbertto Prado|Gilbertto Prado]],[http://www.gilberttoprado.net/ Gilbertto Prado]: CRONOLOGIA DE EXPERIÊNCIAS ARTÍSTICAS NAS REDES DE TELECOMUNICAÇÕES ([http://www.cap.eca.usp.br/wawrwt/textos/gilbertto3.html Web] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425191023/http://www.cap.eca.usp.br/wawrwt/textos/gilbertto3.html |date=2009-04-25 }})[http://www.gilberttoprado.net/ Gilbertto Prado]: Arte telemática: dos intercâmbios pontuais aos ambientes virtuais multiusuário (Itaú Cultural:São Paulo,2003.) ([http://poeticasdigitais.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/2003-arte_telematica_dos_intercambios_pontuais_aos.pdf PDF]) [[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]],[[Mario Costa (philosopher)|Mario Costa]]: ''Internet et globalisation esthétique. L'avenir de l'art et de la philosophie à l'époque des réseaux'', Paris, L'Harmattan, 2003. ([https://books.google.com/books?id=i6xOfK067X0C&pg=PA70 Google books]) [[Caterina Davinio]],[[Caterina Davinio]]: ''Tecno-Poesia e realtà virtuali'' / Techno-Poetry and Virtual Reality, essai (Italian/English). Préface par Eugenio Miccini, Sometti. Collana: ''Archivio della Poesia del 900'', Comune di Mantova, Sometti (I) 2002. Jean-Paul Fourmentraux,Jean-Paul Fourmentraux: ''Art et Internet. les nouvelles figures de la création'', Paris, CNRS Editions, 2005. Louis-José Lestocart,Louis-José Lestocart, ''Epistémologie de la complexité et art contemporain'', Collège de France / PLASTIR, 2007 ([http://www.intelligence-complexite.org/fileadmin/docs/0707ljl.pdf PDF]) Elisa Giaccardi,[http://x.i-dat.org/~eg/ Elisa Giaccardi]: ''Interactive Strategies of Network Art'', Proceedings of CADE '99, Third Conference on Computers in Art & Design Education”, University of Teesside, 7–9 April 1999. [http://l3d.cs.colorado.edu/~giaccard/research/pdf/Giaccardi_CADE99.pdf PDF] [[:fr:Edmond Couchot|Edmond Couchot]] and Norbert Hillaire,[[Edmond Couchot]] et [http://multitudes.samizdat.net/_Hillaire-Norbert_ Norbert Hillaire]: ''L’art numérique'', Éditions Flammarion 2003 Annick BureaudAnnick Bureaud: ''Art and Minitel in France in the 1980s'', in [https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/social-media-archeology-and-poetics ''Social Media Archeology and Poetics'' edited by Judy Malloy, MIT Press, 2016.] recognize the Poietic Generator as one of the historical works of [[digital art]], [[interactive art]], [[generative art]] and [[Net.art]]. Note that the Poietic Generator was born at the time of [[Minitel]], before the invention of the Web (1994), and implemented from 1995 onwards on experimental [[Multicast]] networks foreshadowing [[IPv6]]. The introduction of the Minitel in France, offered, for the first time in the world, an easy way to implement [[telematic art]]. Several French artists attempted somewhat similar experiments,Example of [[telematic art]] using [[Minitel]] : ''Image-la-Vallée'', vitrail monumental dessiné collectivement par minitel, (Jean-Claude Anglade) 1987. ([http://jean.claude.anglade.free.fr/ Web]) but none of them had the durability of Poietic Generator. [[:fr:Anne Cauquelin|Anne Cauquelin]], who deals with the mechanisms of the "system of art" in several of her works,[[:fr:Anne Cauquelin|Anne Cauquelin]]: ''Fréquenter les incorporels'', PUF, collection « Lignes d'art », 2006. ''Que sais-je ? L’art contemporain'', PUF, 9eme édition, mai 2009. considers the Poietic Generator to be the prototype of a new "cognitive art". This new "cognitive art", following [[Marcel Duchamp]], [[Yves Klein]] and [[Andy Warhol]], re-institutes the task of questioning again, and in a more radical way, the "[[doxa]] of art".
Like in the Renaissance, art becomes (a) heuristic, a type of probe with the task to explore a continent.[[:fr:Anne Cauquelin|Anne Cauquelin]], à propros of "cognitive art" in ''L'art contemporain'', PUF (2009), p. 123.
Since 1987, the Poietic Generator directly inspired multiple variations and derivative works. Some of them developed by its original authorOlivier Auber, derivative works of the Poietic Generator: ''[http://wiki.km2.net/wakka.php?wiki=FranceJaponReseau L'Anneau France-Japon, 1988]'' (lauréat du concours du symbole France-Japon, Paris-Kobé, 1988), ''[http://wiki.km2.net/wakka.php?wiki=Schatz Le Trésor des Nibelungen, 2001]'' ([http://km2.net/aplush/nibelungenmuseum/presse/BostonGlobe/BostonGlobe.htm Boston CyberArt 2001], [http://www.liberation.fr/guide/0101356321-tragedies-en-sous-sol ISEA 2001], [http://km2.net/aplush/nibelungenmuseum/communique/sommaire.htm NibelungenMuseum, Worms 2001]), ''[http://arbe.km2.net @rbre (open collective memory), 2000]'' ([http://www.francegenweb.org/blog/index.php?post/2006/05/13/138-l-rbre-un-nouvelle-representation-graphique-de-la-genealogie Tourouvre 2006, Québec 2008]), ''[http://wiki.km2.net/wakka.php?wiki=InvisibleMonument L’Invisible Monument, 2002]'' ([http://km2.net/IMG/jpg/libe10-05-2003-.jpg Metz, 2003]) based on his own research process,Elen S. Riot : [http://wiki.km2.net/PDF/TechnologyReview0308.pdf Olivier Auber, la perspective numérique, in Technology Review, MIT Ed. mars-avril 2008] some of them by other artists and/or researchers, especially [[:fr:Yann Le Guennec|Yann Le Guennec]]Derivative work ([[Free Art Licence]]): ''[http://anoptique.com/wiki/AgregateurPoietique l’Agrégateur Poïétique]'' ([[:fr:Yann Le Guennec|Yann Le Guennec]]) and [[:fr:Albertine Meunier]].Derivative works ([[Free Art Licence]]): ''[http://www.albertinemeunier.net/BigPicture/index.htm BIG PICTURE]'', ''[http://www.albertinemeunier.net/a-petit-pas-vers-l-annonciation/ A petits pas vers l'annonciation, ballet pour angelinos]'' ([[:fr:Albertine Meunier|Albertine Meunier]] 2010) It has also initiated various experiments with some communities, including some contributors of Wikipedia.Derivative experiment: Wikipedia Watchlist, 2006/2008, ([https://web.archive.org/web/20081115043841/http://overcrowded.anoptique.org/ProjetAutographWikipediaWatchlist WebArchive], [[:fr:Générateur Poïétique|meta.wikimedia]]) As a model, the Poietic Generator directly inspired the work of some architects, planners,Atelier urbain du Grand Paris : ''[http://www.ateliergrandparis.com/ateliersdebats/workshop/citebio.php La cité bionumérique]'' social scientists[http://lisard.com/pdfs/creativitybook_final.pdf Workshop Report on Creativity Support Tools, National Science Foundation, June 2005] and anthropologists.Sally A. Applin & Michael Fischer: ''Prospects for Extending User Capabilities Beyond Mixed, Dual and Blended Reality'', Centre for Social Anthropology and Computing, University of Kent Canterbury 2012. [http://www.dfki.de/LAMDa/2012/accepted/PolySocial_Reality.pdf PDF] Indirectly, the Poietic Generator probably inspired many other artists and designers too.Examples of recent works using some Poietic Generator's principles: [http://www.cinematrix.com/games.html Cinematrix] ([[Loren Carpenter]], SIGGRAH, 2006), [https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/magazine/16-07/pb_visualizing Bar chart for words] ([[Martin M. Wattenberg|Martin Wattenberg]], IBM, 2008), [http://rizomer.wordpress.com/2011/07/28/interactive-beings-interactive-documentaries/ Interactive documentaries] (Rizomer, 2011) == Theoretical aspects == === Modelling === Jean-Paul Fourmentraux, in his classificationJean-Paul Fourmentraux, ''[http://tc.revues.org/2872 Les Dispositifs du Net Art]'', 2010 of [[Net.art]] devices, quotes the Poietic Generator as one of the few representatives of the "alteraction" devices category. These type of devices support processes of pure synchronous human communication, free from algorithmic control or introduction of external data. This alteraction process, envisioned as "an intermediate action which makes one become other"[[:fr:Philippe Quéau|Philippe Quéau]] : ''Metaxu : théorie de l'art intermédiaire'', Editions Champ Vallon, 1989 - 337 pages ([[:fr:Philippe Quéau|Philippe Quéau]]), lies outside the field studied by the general [[theory of games]], as its branch covering multiplayer games ([[coordination game]]s, [[cooperative game]]s) which does not consider the [[emergence]] of meta-levels: specifically the "becoming other". According to testimony, the Poietic Generator has an amazing ability to immerse its players in a learning process of social phenomena: it gives not only the possibility to live a kind of "conversation", but in some degree, to access to its model by observing and interpreting autopoietic phenomena, that is to say the "life", which takes place there. According to Olivier Auber, there would be in the Poietic Generator, intrusion of eigenfrequencies, similar to those existing in other autopoietic systems (cell, cerebral cortex, etc.).Jean Petitot, [http://jean.petitot.pagesperso-orange.fr/JPmodeles.html ''Modèles dynamiques en Sciences cognitives''] Despite their apparent complexity, these temporal phenomena (oscillations between structure and chaos, complexity and simplicity) could be analyzed, even "mathematised",Olivier Auber : [http://perspective-numerique.net/PDF/RecherchePerspectivesAnoptiques.pdf ''Perspectives anoptiques : théorie et applications'' PDF] particularly in the light of the [[simplicity theory]][http://www.simplicitytheory.org/ ''simplicity theory'' ([[Jean-Louis Dessalles]], Telecom Paristech, 2008)][https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.08657 Saillenfest, A., Dessalles, J-L., Auber, O. (2016). Role of Simplicity in Creative Behaviour: The Case of the Poietic Generator. Proceedings of the Seventh International Conference on Computational Creativity (ICCC-2016). Paris, France. (PDF)] ([[Jean-Louis Dessalles]]). Structuring phases corresponds to a "becoming other" (Quéau) and a greater "simplicity" (Dessalles). The emergence of these kinds of paradigm shifts would be both unexpected and [[determinism|deterministic]]. === Perspectives === The Poietic Generator may be seen as a generic modelLenay, C. (1988): ''Création collective et émergence de signes : l'oeuvre d'Olivier Auber'', published in Actes du séminaire interdisciplinaire de Sciences Cognitives et Epistémologie "Genèse des Représentations" - 01/1995 - p. 139-148, online on [https://www.academia.edu/31940266/Cr%C3%A9ation_collective_et_%C3%A9mergence_de_signes Academia] of multiple complex systems (informational, urban, economic, ecological, etc.) to which everyone is confronted daily. But unlike these systems, often opaque about their prerequisites, their rules and infrastructure, the Poietic Generator is perfectly transparent: "everything is known or knowable", in particular the fact that it operates either centrally or without any center. According to Olivier Auber,As discussed by Inge Hinterwaldner in ''The Systemic Image: A New Theory of Interactive Real-Time Simulations'', MIT Press (2016) - p. 28, 29, 283, 326, 327, 386. Available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=XT3mDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA326&lpg=PA326&dq=%22Du+%22g%C3%A9n%C3%A9rateur+po%C3%AF%C3%A9tique%22+%C3%A0+la+perspective+num%C3%A9rique%22&source=bl&ots=luXR2A3N6V&sig=dFahWS0MJh1kq9-vlh4UjZ7zSek&hl=fr&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Auber&f=false Google Books] these two architectures, centered or not, are achieving some forms of "[[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]]" (within the meaning of the Renaissance) in which the vanishing point lies, in the first case, in a physical center (the server), in the second in a "code" under cover of which the network is sharing information (its sign of recognition in some way). He speaks in the first case of a "temporal perspective" because it is in the center where emerges moment by moment the "proper time" of the network (its rhythmic pulsations). In the second case, he speaks of a "digital perspective"Olivier Auber : ''Du Générateur poïétique à la perspective numérique'', Revue d'esthétique 43 - 07/2003 - p. 127, online on [http://archee.qc.ca/ar.php?page=imp&no=207 Archée, Québec], "The Aestetic of the Digital Perspective", Artmedia VIII, Paris, 2002 ([http://vv.arts.ucla.edu/publications/publications/02-03/Artmedia/PARTICIPANTSe.htm arts.ucla.edu]) because it is a "code" (an arbitrary number) which is the guarantor of the emergence of the proper time of the network in each of its nodes. These two perspectives are of course not visual as is the case of the spatial perspective, but they share with it some topological and symbolic attributes. In particular, one can speak of "legitimate perspective", as [[Leon Battista Alberti|Alberti]] did in the [[Renaissance]]. The Poietic Generator as an [[Ideal city]], implements these two non-visual perspectives, described by Oliver Auber "anoptical perspectives," as perfectly and obvious as possible. Throughout the game, players can gradually take a cognitive step back, and by analogy grasp in thought the nature of the perspectives in question. The hypothesis of Olivier Auber is that these perspectives are exercised within the framework of "real" systems, opaque and complex as mentioned above, and that they shape the imagination and judgment, that is to say the [[doxa]] of those who are enrolled in it. In attempting to uncover the "anoptical perspectives", the Poietic Generator positions itself as a [[metagaming|metagame]] which invites a questioning of the processes of social interaction, especially when they are mediated by technological devices interacting with [[social networks]].De nouvelles perspectives pour les « réseaux sociaux ?», conférence dans les cadre des « Entretiens du nouveau monde industriel », Centre Georges Pompidou, 4 octobre 2008 ([http://amateur.iri.centrepompidou.fr/nouveaumonde/enmi/ldt/index/xolivierauber vidéo]) For Olivier Auber, the Poietic Generator, as a model and experience available to all, could contribute to "a certain conceptual knowledge (dianoia) of how the doxa is formed and exercised on us, especially through technology". At a time when technical objects are close to the body and are preparing to invade it, the Poietic Generator could help us by providing "a set of conceptual tools for the new "perspecteurs" ([[Abraham Bosse]]) that we could all become" in order, he says, to "rethink the imagination of the technology in full light".Olivier Auber : Perspectives anoptiques : théorie et applications, ibid. == Reception by the institutions of research, culture and media ==
Attempts like this are crucial to emancipate the technology from the status a mere instrument for defined purposes, and to recognize the role that it should have as a creator of culture and practices.[[Isabelle Stengers]], [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/stengers.gif lettre de soutien, 1995]
Since the 1990s, many scientists in all disciplines, mentioned the Poietic Generator as a model which may help to rethink the cultural, even anthropological changing, latent in networks, and especially emphasized the urgency of a "redefinition of the notion of authorship".Anne Sauvageot et Michel Léglise, ''Culture visuelle et art collectif sur le web'' (PDF)], rapport au Ministère de la Culture et de la Communication, 1999 ([http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/actualites/rapports/sauvageot-leglise/art_col_web.pdf PDF]) Some of these researchersSome scientists supporting the Poietic Generator : [[Francisco Varela]] (biology) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/varela.gif lettre], [[Paul Virilio]] (urbanism and philosophy) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/virilio.gif lettre], [[Isabelle Stengers]] (history of science) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/stengers.gif lettre], [[Bernard Stiegler]] (philosophy) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/stiegler.gif lettre], [[:fr:Jean-Pierre Dupuy|Jean-Pierre Dupuy]] (philosophy) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/dupuy.gif lettre], [[w:en:Roy ascott|Roy Ascott]] (digital arts) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/ascott.gif lettre], [[Fred Forest]] (media art) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/forest.gif lettre], [[:fr:Jean-Pierre Le Goff (historian)|Jean-Pierre Le Goff]] (history of science)- [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/legoff.gif lettre], [[Pierre Lévy]] (cognitive sciences) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/levy.gif lettre], [http://cricc.univ-paris1.fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=15&Itemid=18 Isabelle Rieusset-Lemarié] (humanities) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/rieusset.gif lettre], [http://www.ehess.fr/fr/enseignement/enseignements/2012/enseignant/307/ Michel Tibon-Cornillot] (history of sciences), [http://liris.cnrs.fr/enaction/docs/fiches2008/CharlesLenay.html Charles Lenay] (history of sciences) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/lenay.gif lettre], [[:fr:René Passeron|René Passeron]] (esthetics) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/passeron.gif lettre], [http://chavalarias.com/tiki-index.php?page=Louis+Bec+%3A+L%27art+est+le+vivant&bl=y Louis Bec] (artificial life) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/bec.gif lettre], [http://www.cnrs.fr/cw/dossiers/dosrob/accueil/laboratoires/labo/tuteur.html Philippe Coiffet] (robotics) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/coiffet.gif lettre], [http://www.twobirds.com/French/Lawyers/Pages/Pierre_Sirinelli1.aspx Pierre Sirinelli] (law) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/siri.gif lettre], [http://www.sgdl.org/toutes-les-actualites/718-notice-biographique-de-sandra-travers-de-faultrier Sandra Travers de Faultrier] (law) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/faultrier.gif lettre], [http://www.lactamme.polytechnique.fr/ Jean-François Colonna] (mathematics) - [http://poietic-generator.net/PICS/lettres/colonna.gif lettre] brought in a personal support to attempts to practice large-scale experiments using channels such as broadcast television stations, museums, public places, etc. Without listening and support from these institutional broadcasters,Olivier Auber : 'Grandeur et déchéance programmée de l'art numérique en France'' 2011 ([http://perspective-numerique.net/wakka.php?wiki=GrandeurEtDecheanceProgrammee Web]) very few of these projects have been successful. Handicapped by its transdisciplinary or even "undisciplinary" nature, and naturally questioning the legitimacy of human organizations to which it is dealing with, the [[action research]] on the Poietic Generator has never found any other field to flourish as the Internet itself. Nevertheless, the Poietic Generator and writings of its author are quoted in many academic thesis,''Le copyleft appliqué à la création hors logiciel. Une reformulation des données culturelles ?'', Antoine Moreau, Université de Nice, 2011 ([http://antoinemoreau.org/index.php?cat=these Web]), ''Sémiotique de la représentation de soi dans les dispositifs interactifs'', Fanny Georges, Paris I, 2007 ([http://fannygeorges.free.fr/FGeorges_These_0108.pdf PDF]), ''Le Net-art, témoin d'une ère post-nationale'', Isabelle Lassignardie, Université de Pau, 2003 ([http://it.scribd.com/doc/34829333/Isabelle-Lassignardie-Net-art-Annexes Web], ''Quand un média devient médium'' Cécile Wekler, Université Paris 3, 2006 ([http://f.hypotheses.org/wp-content/blogs.dir/220/files/2010/09/memoire_M2_C.Welker.pdf PDF]), ''L’interactivité dans le Web-art'' Jean-Davis Boussemaer, Université Grenoble 3, 2003 ([http://jdb2.free.fr/PDF/MAITRISE/Corps.pdf PDF]), ''Mario Costa et l'esthétique de la communication'', Amélie Hamon, Université Paris I, 2006. ([http://www.observatoire-critique.org/IMG/MEMOIRE%20MARIO%20COSTA.pdf PDF]), ''L'art numérique: médiation et mises en exposition d'une esthétique communicationnelle'', Lauren Malka, Paris IV, 2005. [http://www.memoireonline.com/08/07/547/m_art-numerique-mediation-mises-en-exposition-esthetique-communicationnelle12.html Web], ''Les grandes images", Julien Piedpremier, Paris VIII, 2005. [http://www.almasola.net/these_JulienPiedpremier.pdf PDF], ''Art Libre : Un enchevêtrement de réseaux discursifs et créatifs ?'', Charlotte Bruge. Lille III, 2003 [http://artlibre.org/wp-content/dea.pdf PDF], ''Art Internet, anatomie de l'echange'', Eric Le Maillot, Groupe EAC, 2006 [http://www.memoireonline.com/06/09/2125/m_Art-Internet-anatomie-de-l-echange.html Web] and in at least one "100% plagiarized".Étude sur une thèse 100% plagiée (diffusée pendant plusieurs années par l'ANRT) reprenant les textes d'olivier Auber : [http://archeologie-copier-coller.com/?p=7475 ''Archéologie du copier-coller'', Jean Noël darde] ==See also== * {{annotated link|Autopoiesis}} * {{annotated link|Poiesis}} * {{annotated link|Game classification}} * {{annotated link|Game theory}} * {{annotated link|Doxa}} * {{annotated link|Telematic art}} * {{annotated link|Net.art}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://poietic-generator.net/blog/ Poietic Generator (official site)] * [http://perspective-numerique.net Digital perspective] * [http://anoptique.org Anoptique] * [http://wiki.km2.net/wakka.php?wiki=PublicationsGenerateurPoietique Press release] [[Category:Net.artists]] [[Category:Digital art]]

Rna22 is a pattern-based algorithm for the discovery of [[microRNA]] target sites and the corresponding heteroduplexes.{{cite journal |vauthors=Miranda KC, Huynh T, Tay Y, Ang YS, Tam WL, Thomson AM, Lim B, Rigoutsos I |title=A pattern-based method for the identification of MicroRNA binding sites and their corresponding heteroduplexes. |journal=Cell |volume=126 |issue=6 |pages=1203–17 |year=2006 |pmid=16990141 |doi=10.1016/j.cell.2006.07.031}} The algorithm is conceptually distinct from other methods for predicting [[List of RNA structure prediction software#Inter molecular interactions: MicroRNA:UTR|microRNA:mRNA heteroduplexes]] in that it does ''not'' use experimentally validated heteroduplexes for training, instead relying only on the sequences of known mature miRNAs that are found in the public databases. The key idea of rna22 is that the reverse complement of any salient sequence features that one can identify in mature microRNA sequences (using pattern discovery techniques) should allow one to identify candidate microRNA target sites in a sequence of interest: rna22 makes use of the [[Teiresias algorithm]] to discover such salient features. Once a candidate microRNA target site has been located, the targeting microRNA can be identified with the help of any of several algorithms able to compute RNA:RNA heteroduplexes. A new version (v2.0) of the algorithm is now available: v2.0-beta adds probability estimates to each prediction, gives users the ability to choose the sensitivity/specificity settings on-the-fly, is significantly faster than the original, and can be accessed through http://cm.jefferson.edu/rna22/Interactive/. Rna22 neither relies on nor imposes any cross-organism conservation constraints to filter out unlikely candidates; this gives it the ability to discover microRNA binding sites that may not be conserved in phylogenetically proximal organisms. Also, as mentioned above, rna22 can identify putative microRNA binding sites without needing to know the identity of the targeting microRNA. A notable property of rna22 is that it does ''not'' require the presence of the exact reverse complement of a microRNA's seed in a putative target permitting bulges and G:U wobbles in the seed region of the heteroduplex. Lastly, the algorithm has been shown to achieve high signal-to-noise ratio.{{cite journal |vauthors=Ritchie W, Flamant S, Rasko JE |title=Predicting microRNA targets and functions: traps for the unwary. |journal=Nature Methods |volume=6 |issue=6 |pages=397–8 |year=2009 |pmid=19478799 |doi=10.1038/nmeth0609-397}} Use of rna22 led to the discovery of "non-canonical" microRNA targets in the coding regions of the mouse ''Nanog'', ''Oct4'' and ''Sox2''.{{cite journal |vauthors=Tay Y, Zhang J, Thomson AM, Lim B, Rigoutsos I |title=MicroRNAs to ''Nanog'', ''Oct4'' and ''Sox2'' coding regions modulate embryonic stem cell differentiation. |journal=Nature |volume=455 |issue=7126 |pages=1124–8 |year=2008 |pmid=18806776 | doi=10.1038/nature07299 }} Most of these targets are not conserved in the human orthologues of these three transcription factors even though they reside in the coding region of the corresponding mRNAs. Moreover, most of these targets contain G:U wobbles, one or more bulges, or both, in the seed region of the heteroduplex. In addition to coding regions, rna22 has helped discover non-canonical targets in 3'UTRs.{{cite journal |vauthors=Lal A, Navarro F, Maher CA, Maliszewski LE, Yan N, O'Day E, Chowdhury D, Dykxhoorn DM, Tsai P, Hofmann O, Becker KG, Gorospe M, Hide W, Lieberman J |title=miR-24 inhibits cell proliferation by targeting E2F2, MYC, and other cell-cycle genes via binding to "seedless" 3'UTR microRNA recognition elements. |journal=Mol Cell |volume=35 |issue=5 |pages=610–25 |year=2009 |pmid=19748357 | doi=10.1016/j.molcel.2009.08.020 |pmc=2757794}} A recent study{{cite journal |vauthors=Xia Z, Clark P, Huynh T, Loher P, Zhao Y, Chen HW, Rigoutsos I, Zhou R |title=Molecular dynamics simulations of Ago silencing complexes reveal a large repertoire of admissible 'seed-less' targets. |journal=Scientific Reports |volume=2 |year=2012 |doi=10.1038/srep00569 |pmid=22888400 |pmc=3415692}} examined the problem of non-canonical miRNA targets using molecular dynamics simulations of the crystal structure of the Argonaute-miRNA:mRNA ternary complex. The study found that several kinds of modifications, including combinations of multiple G:U wobbles and mismatches in the seed region, are admissible and result in only minor structural fluctuations that do not affect the stability of the ternary complex. The study also showed that the findings of the molecular dynamics simulation are supported by [[HITS-CLIP]] (CLIP-seq) data. These results suggest that ''bona fide'' miRNA targets transcend the canonical seed-model in turn making target prediction tools like rna22 an ideal choice for exploring the newly augmented spectrum of miRNA targets. {| class="wikitable" ! Name ! Description || type|| Link || References |- |'''RNA22 version 2.0''' |The first web-site link (interactive & dynamic) permits the user to find on-the-fly putative miRNA binding sites for any sequence of interest (i.e. a protein-coding mRNA, or long non-coding RNA) and for any miRNA (publicly known or novel). The second link{{cite journal |vauthors=Loher P, Rigoutsos I |title=Interactive exploration of RNA22 microRNA target predictions. |journal=Bioinformatics |volume=28 |issue=24 |pages=3322–3323 |year=2012 |pmid=23074262 |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts615}} (precomputed & static) provides access to RNA22 v2 predictions for all protein coding transcripts in human, mouse, roundworm, and fruit fly. It allows the user to visualize the predictions within a cDNA map and also find transcripts where multiple miRNA's of interest target. || [[List of RNA structure prediction software#Inter molecular interactions: MicroRNA:UTR|microRNA target predictions]] || [http://cm.jefferson.edu/rna22/Interactive/ interactive predictions]

'''Repetition blindness''' ('''RB''') is a phenomenon observed in [[rapid serial visual presentation]]. People are sometimes poor at recognizing when things happen twice. Repetition blindness is the failure to recognize a second happening of a visual display. The two displays are shortly shown usually for about 150 milliseconds, and then they are shown within 500 milliseconds of each other (Kanwisher, 1987).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kanwisher|first=N|title=Repetition blindness: Type recognition without token individuation|journal=Cognition|year=1987|volume=27|pages=117–143|doi=10.1016/0010-0277(87)90016-3|pmid=3691023}}</ref> Repetition blindness tasks usually are words in lists and in sentences. They are called phonologically similar items (Bavelier & Potter, 1992).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bavelier|first=D|author2=Potter, M |title=Visual and phonological codes in repetition blindness|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance|year=1992}}</ref> There are also pictures, and words that include pictures. An example of this is a picture of the sun and the word sun (Bavelier, 1994).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bavelier|first=D|title=Repetition blindness between visually different items: The case of pictures and words|journal=Cognition|year=1994|issue=3|pages=199–236|doi=10.1016/0010-0277(94)90054-x|volume=51}}</ref> The most popular task used to examine repetition blindness is to show words one after another on a screen fast in which participants must recall the words that they saw. This task is known as the rapid serial visual presentation (RSVP). Repetition blindness is present if missing the second word creates an inaccurate sentence. An example of this is "When she spilled the ink there was ink all over.” An RSVP sequence participants will recall seeing "When she spilled the ink there was all over." However, they are missing the second occurrence of "ink" (Kanwisher, 1987). This finding supports that people are "blind" for the second occurrence of a repetitive item in an RSVP series. For example, a subject's chances of correctly reporting both appearances of the word "cat" in the RSVP stream "dog mouse cat elephant cat snake" are lower than their chances of reporting the third and fifth words in the stream "dog mouse cat elephant pig snake".
The precise mechanism underlying RB has been extensively debated. [[Nancy Kanwisher]] has argued that it involves failure to [[tokenize]] the second appearance of a repeated stimulus, leading to the second appearance being dropped from short term memory before it can be reported. However, Whittlesea and colleagues have argued that repetition blindness arises from a failure to properly reconstruct the list, both online and post list. This failure to properly reconstruct the list arises from the poor encoding cues that are the result of the RSVP task.

{{refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Platonism}} The '''Ship of State''' is a famous and oft-cited [[metaphor]] put forth by [[Plato]] in Book VI of the ''[[The Republic (Plato)|Republic]]'' (488a–489d). It likens the [[governance]] of a [[city-state]] to the command of a naval vessel and ultimately argues that the only men fit to be [[Captain (nautical)|captain]] of this [[ship]] ({{lang-grc-gre|ναῦς}}) are [[philosopher king]]s, benevolent men with absolute power who have access to [[the Form of the Good]]. The origins of the metaphor can be traced back to the lyric poet [[Alcaeus of Mytilene|Alcaeus]] (frs. 6, 208, 249), and it is found in [[Sophocles]]’ [[Antigone]] and [[Aeschylus]]' [[Seven Against Thebes]] before Plato.
==Plato's use of the metaphor== Plato establishes the comparison by saying that [[God]] was one of the best models of describing the steering of a ship as just like any other "craft" or [[profession]] — in particular, that of a [[Politician|statesman]]. He then runs the metaphor in reference to a particular type of government: [[democracy]]. Plato’s democracy is not the modern notion of a mix of democracy and [[republic]]anism, but rather direct democracy by way of pure majority rule. In the metaphor, found at 488a-489d, Plato's Socrates compares the population at large to a strong but nearsighted shipowner whose knowledge of seafaring is lacking. The quarreling sailors are demagogues and politicians, and the ship's navigator, a stargazer, is the philosopher. The sailors flatter themselves with claims to knowledge of sailing, though they know nothing of navigation, and are constantly vying with one another for the approval of the shipowner so to captain the ship, going so far as to stupefy the shipowner with drugs and wine. Meanwhile, they dismiss the navigator as a useless stargazer, though he is the only one with adequate knowledge to direct the ship's course.
==The Ship of State since Plato== It has been routinely referenced throughout [[Western culture]] ever since its inception; two notable literary examples are [[Horace|Horace's]] [[Odes (Horace)|ode]] 1.14 and "[[O Ship of State]]" by [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]]. [[Roger Williams]], the founder of Rhode Island, used the metaphor in his Letter to the Town of Providence (1656).
More recently, it has become a staple of American political discussion, where it is viewed simply as its image of the state as a ship, in need of a government as officers to command it – and conspicuously absent of its anti-democratic, pro-[[Autocracy|absolutist]] original meaning.
The term has entered popular culture as well. [[Leonard cohen|Leonard Cohen]]'s song "Democracy" contains the line "Sail on. Sail on, o mighty ship of state. To the shores of need, past the reefs of greed, through the squalls of hate." Also, in his second novel 'Beautiful Losers' (1966) Cohen writes "Sail on, sail on, O Ship of State, auto accidents, births, Berlin, cures for cancer!" (p. 12). In the British TV series [[Yes, Minister]], [[Sir Humphrey|Sir Humphrey Appleby]] pointed out that "the Ship of State is the only ship that leaks from the top".<ref>Season 3, episode 5 ("The Bed of Nails") at ca 25:33 mins</ref>
===Actual ocean liners=== Beyond the political metaphor, in the 20th century "Ship of State" became a term applied to [[ocean liner]]s which were built to be floating symbols of a state's artistic and technological advancement; normally [[flagship]]s of the country's most successful passenger shipping line, and the construction of which was often subsidised by the state government. Examples of liners considered Ships of State are the [[RMS Queen Mary|RMS ''Queen Mary'']] ([[United Kingdom]]), [[SS Normandie|SS ''Normandie'']] ([[France]]), [[SS Rex|SS ''Rex'']] ([[Italy]]), [[SS France (1961)|SS ''France'']] (France), [[RMS Queen Mary 2|RMS ''Queen Mary 2'']] (United Kingdom), and [[SS United States|SS ''United States'']] ([[United States]]). <!-- == References == <references />-->
==See also== * [[Allegorical Interpretations of Plato]] * [[Plato's political philosophy]] * [[Spaceship Earth]] * [[Collective intelligence]]
==External links== *Longfellow's "[http://poetry.poetryx.com/poems/6310/ O Ship of State]." *Text of [http://classics.mit.edu/Plato/republic.7.vi.html book VI] of Plato's ''Republic''.

[[Image:Snoezelroom.jpg|thumb|Children in a "snoezelroom"]] [[Image:Snoezelruimte.JPG|thumb|Room for Snoezelen therapy in the home of a child with a developmental disability in the Netherlands]]
'''Snoezelen''' or '''controlled multisensory environment''' ('''MSE''') is a therapy for people with [[autism]] and other [[developmental disability|developmental disabilities]], [[dementia]] or [[Acquired brain injury|brain injury]]. It consists of placing the person in a soothing and stimulating environment, called the "Snoezelen room". These rooms are specially designed to deliver stimuli to various [[senses]], using lighting effects, color, sounds, music, scents, etc. The combination of different materials on a wall may be explored using tactile senses, and the floor may be adjusted to stimulate the [[sense of balance]]. The person is usually accompanied by an aide or therapist.
Developed in the [[Netherlands]] in the 1970s, Snoezelen rooms have been established in institutions all over the world and are especially common in [[Germany]], where more than 1,200 exist.
There is no evidence that Snoezelen is effective for the treatment of dementia.<ref name=Cochrane /> ==Term== The term "Snoezelen" (pronounced {{IPA|/ˈsnuzələ(n)/}}) is a [[neologism]] formed from a blend of the [[Dutch language|Dutch]] "snuffelen" (to snuggle, also: to sniff) and "doezelen" (to doze, to snooze). It was coined by Jan Hulsegge and Ad Verheul who developed the concept while working at [[De Hartenberg Institute]] in the Netherlands.
==Approach== Ideally, Snoezelen is a non-directive therapy, controlled by the client and not by the therapist. It can be staged to provide a multi-sensory experience or single sensory focus, simply by adapting the lighting, atmosphere, sounds, and textures to the specific needs of the client at the time of use. There is no formal focus on therapeutic outcome—the focus is to assist users to gain the maximum pleasure from the activity in which they and the enabler are involved. An advantage of Snoezelen therapy is that it does not rely on verbal communication and may be beneficial for people with profound autism, as it may provide stimulation for those who would otherwise be almost impossible to reach.
Snoezelen therapy relates to the interdependence of both the space (the physical environment) and the "client-centered" approach of the practitioner (the human environment). The specially designed sensory physical environment together with the input of the "enabling practitioner" initiates changes in arousal by affecting the relaxation process, reducing anxiety/pain (both physical and emotional).<ref>Shapiro et al., 1997; 2009a; 2009b; Fornes, Messbauer, Pagliano & Verheul, 2009</ref> It aims to maximize a person's potential to focus on his own free will and to engage on a motivational stimulus (object, activity or person), and thereby to improve communication and functioning.
The defining principles of the MSE help the practitioner to focus attention on the basic elements of this approach. The following are the principles.
# The experience takes place in a specific physical environment. # The attitude of the practitioners is "client centered". # Stimuli must be controlled according to the client's needs. # The MSE is a medium for communication. # The sensory environment is neither positive nor negative. # The practitioner relies on the client's point of view. (Shapiro, 2010).
==Research== Research on the benefits of Snoezelen treatment is scarce, with variable [[clinical study design|study designs]].<ref name=Cochrane>Chung JCC, Lai CKY. Snoezelen for dementia. ''The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews'' 2002, Issue '''4'''. Art. No.: [http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/cochrane/clsysrev/articles/CD003152/frame.html CD003152]. {{doi|10.1002/14651858.CD003152}}.</ref><ref>Lancioni GE, Cuvo AJ, O'Reilly MF. Snoezelen: an overview of research with people with developmental disabilities and dementia. ''Disabil Rehabil.'' 2002; '''24''': 175-84. {{PMID|11926258}}</ref>
A small research study carried out in Brussels compared the behavior of nine adult clients with profound autism in both classroom and Snoezelen settings. Though individual results varied, the study claimed a 50% reduction in distress and stereotypical behavior, and seventy-five percent less aggression and self-injury in the Snoezelen environment.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www6.miami.edu/ummedicine-magazine/fall2004/journal.html#mjstory7 Report on the use of a snoezelen room] at [[Jackson Memorial Hospital]], fall 2004

{{medref|date=December 2014}}
'''Somatic experiencing''' is a form of [[alternative medicine|alternative therapy]] aimed at relieving the symptoms of [[post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) and other mental and physical trauma-related health problems by focusing on the client's perceived body sensations (or somatic experiences). It was created by trauma therapist Peter A. Levine.<ref>{{cite book|last1=van der Kolk|first1=Bessel|author-link=Bessel van der Kolk|title=The Body Keeps the Score: Brain, Mind, and Body in the Healing of Trauma|date=2014|publisher=Penguin|isbn=9781101608302|page=217|language=en}}</ref>
Sessions are normally done in person, and involve a client tracking his or her own experience.<ref name="Scaer 2005">Scaer, Robert C.: ''The Trauma Spectrum. Hidden Wounds and Human Resiliency''. W.W. Norton & Company, N.Y. & London, 2005</ref>{{rp|255–256}} Practitioners are often mental health practitioners such as social workers, psychologists, marriage and family therapists (MFTs) or psychotherapists, but may also be nurses, physicians, [[Bodywork (alternative medicine)|bodyworkers]], physical therapists, chaplains, clergy, or members of other professions. Certified practitioners complete a three-year training course (216 hours of instruction) and must complete 18 hours of case consultations and 12 hours of personal sessions.<ref>[http://www.seaustralia.com.au/somatic-experiencing-australia_professional_training/ Somatic experiencing Australia training], Retrieved 2 April 2018</ref> Somatic Experiencing is used for shock trauma in the short term and for developmental trauma as an adjunct to psychotherapy that may span years.
Somatic Experiencing attempts to promote awareness and release physical tension that remains in the aftermath of trauma.<ref name="Scaer 2005"/>{{rp|43–50}}<ref name="Scaer 2001">{{cite book|last1=Scaer|first1=Robert C.|title=The Body Bears the Burden: Trauma, Dissociation, and Disease|date=2001|publisher=The Haworth Press|isbn=0789033348|pages=275|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Body_Bears_the_Burden.html?id=C30EbO7GDMIC|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>{{rp|38–40}}
==Methods==
Another element of Somatic Experiencing therapy is "pendulation",<ref name="Scaer 2005"/>{{rp|255}} the movement between regulation and dysregulation. The client is helped to move to a state where he or she is dysregulated (i.e. is aroused or frozen, demonstrated by physical symptoms such as pain or numbness) and then iteratively helped to return to a state of regulation. The goal is to allow the client to resolve the physical and mental difficulties caused by the trauma, and thereby to be able to respond appropriately to everyday situations.<ref>[http://www.mary-ware.com/how-does-se-work.html Mary ware Somatic Experiencing], Retrieved 2 April 2018</ref>
"Resources" are defined as anything that helps the client's [[autonomic nervous system]] return to a regulated state. This might be the memory of someone close to them, a physical item that might ground them in the present moment, or other supportive elements that minimize distress. In the face of arousal, "discharge" is facilitated to allow the client's body to return to a regulated state. Discharge may be in the form of tears, a warm sensation, unconscious movement, the ability to breathe easily again, or other responses which demonstrate the autonomic nervous system returning to its baseline. The intention of this process is to reinforce the client's inherent capacity to self-regulate.
Somatic experiencing is used for both shock trauma and developmental trauma. Shock trauma is loosely defined as a single-episode traumatic event such as a car accident, natural disaster such as an earthquake, battlefield incident, physical attack, etc.<ref>[https://www.gomentor.com/articles/shock-trauma Gomentor shock trauma], Retrieved 2 April 2018</ref> Developmental trauma refers to various kinds of psychological damage that occur during child development when a child has insufficient or detrimental attention from the primary caregivers.<ref name="Scaer 2005" />{{rp|99–125}}{{Request quotation|date=December 2016}}<ref>[http://weinholds.org/what-is-developmental-trauma-2/ Weinholds developmental trauma], retrieved 2 April 2018</ref>
==See also== * [[Body psychotherapy]] * [[Psychosomatic medicine]]

*[[Decibel|dB]], decibel - noise of sound measurement is called decibels (dB). Ratio of the sound pressure to reference pressure to something. *[[sone]] - a unit of perceived loudness equal to the loudness of a 1000-hertz tone at 40 dB above [[Absolute threshold of hearing|threshold]], starting with 1 sone. *[[phon]] - a unit of subjective [[loudness]]. *[[hertz|Hz]], hertz = unit of sound frequency is called hertz (Hz)

'''Threatcasting''' is a conceptual framework used to help multidisciplinary groups envision future scenarios. It is also a process that enables systematic planning against threats ten years in the future. Utilizing the threatcasting process, groups explore possible future threats and how to transform the future they desire into reality while avoiding undesired futures. Threatcasting is a continuous, multiple-step process with inputs from social science, technical research, cultural history, economics, trends, expert interviews, and science fiction storytelling. These inputs inform the exploration of potential visions of the future.
Once inputs are explored for impact and application, participants create a science fiction story ([[Science fiction prototyping|Science Fiction Prototyping]]) based ten years in the future to add context around human activity. Science Fiction Prototyping consists of a future story about a person in a place doing a thing. The threatcasting process results in creation of many potential futures scenarios - some futures are desirable while others are not. Identifying both types of futures (desirable and undesirable) will help the participant recognize which future to aim toward, and which to avoid. Utilizing the scenarios, participants plot actions necessary in the present and at various intervals working toward the ten year future scenario. These actions will help participants understand how to empower or disrupt the target future scenario. Flags (warning events) are also determined in order to map societal indicators onto the recommended path toward the targeted future. When identified flags appear in society, threatcasting participants map these back to the original forecast to see whether or not they are on track toward the target future scenario.
== Origins == {{see also|Science fiction prototyping}}
The notion of threatcasting can be traced back to Brian David Johnson, an applied futurist, who first began using threatcasting, also referred to as futurecasting, in 2011 and to George Hemingway of the Stratalis Group<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stratalisgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/MMStratalisFuturecasting1.pdf|title=Futurecasting the Mining Industry|last=|first=|date=January 2013|website=Stratalis Group|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>, who pioneered notion of futurecasting for corporate strategy and innovation industrial markets, including mining<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stratalisgroup.com/futurecasting-the-power-of-foresight/|title=The Stratalis Group {{!}} Futurecasting: The Power of Foresight – The Final in a Six Part Series|website=www.stratalisgroup.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-29}}</ref> in the same year. Early adopters of threatcasting include the [[United States Air Force Academy]], the [[Government of California]], and the Army Cyber Institute at [[United States Military Academy|West Point Military Academy]]. Official use of the term threatcasting is attributed to Brian David Johnson in a 2014 Gazette article “Drones, smart hydrants considered by experts looking at future of firefighting.”<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://gazette.com/drones-smart-hydrants-considered-by-experts-looking-at-future-of-firefighting/article/1515148|title=Drones, smart hydrants considered by experts looking at future of firefighting|newspaper=Colorado Springs Gazette|access-date=2017-02-21}}</ref>
== Differences between Threatcasting and Strategic Planning == Threatcasting is fundamentally different from traditional [[strategic planning]] and [[Scenario analysis|scenario building]] processes due to the identification of specific actions, indicators and concrete steps that can be taken today to disrupt, mitigate and recover from future threats.
== Applications == The Army Cyber Institute at West Point in conjunction with [[Arizona State University Polytechnic campus|Arizona State University's]] Global Securities Initiative and the School for the Future of Innovation in Society have established a Threatcasting Lab to host and manage a Cyber Threatcasting Project which looks to envision future cyber threats ten years in the future. The first session of this collaborative group was held at West Point, NY in August 2016.
